results.title: Eskimo winter
results.creator_credit: Richard Robinson, George Pearson, Michael McKennirey, Brian Branston, British Broadcasting Corporation and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “People of the Seal”.
The second of two co-productions by the British Broadcasting Corporation and the National Film Board of Canada, People of the Seal, Part 2: Eskimo Winter is compiled from some of the most vivid footage ever filmed of the life of the Netsilik Inuit in the Pelly Bay region of the Canadian Arctic. Together, the two films provide insight and understanding of a culture now almost vanished, as they show the incredible resourcefulness of the Netsilik (People of the Seal) who have adapted to one of the world’s harshest environments. Part 2: Eskimo Winter shows how Inuit families gather in communities on the sea ice to harpoon seal as they come up through breathing holes in the ice. Also seen is the mid-winter season, a time of intense socialising in the communal igloo, with games, contests and ceremonial activities. (Awards: Salerno; Trento) Narrated by Alexander Scourby

results.title: Eric & Ernie's Xmas Show = The Morecambe & Wise Christmas Show
results.brief_description: A selection of comedy sketches by one of Britain’s favourite TV comedy duos, Eric Morecambe and Ernie Wise, from their Christmas shows. Guests include Peter Barkworth, Peter Cushing, Hannah Gordon, Glenda Jackson, Mick McManus, Gemma Craven, Jill Gascoine, Sir Alec Guinness, Peter Vaughan.

results.title: Equality. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Art Ciocco, Paul Buck, Ken Stein, New Jersey Public Television and Best Films
results.brief_description: Explores the diversity of people and the breadth of the problems as one searches for “equality”. Concentrates on the basic areas of economics, ethnic groups, problems of old age and alternate lifestyle. Contains some b&w sequences.

results.title: Building dreams
results.creator_credit: Yuri Sokol, Michael Le Moignan and Corroboree Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Black futures (A)”.
Until recently, the 150,000 Australians who are of Aboriginal descent had little hope of ever owning a home or getting a permanent job. Now, young Aboriginal building apprentices are putting up first class new homes for their own communities. Better living conditions are helping Aboriginal people to maintain their own distinct sense of identity and boosting their self-confidence.

results.title: Getting better
results.creator_credit: Yuri Sokol, Larry Lucas, Michael Le Moignan, Australian Film Commission and Corroboree Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Black futures (A)”.
The life expectancy of Australian Aborigines is twenty years less than white life expectancy. But things are changing. Aboriginal people are taking control of their own health care. They are trying to combine the best elements of Western medicine with traditional remedies.

results.title: Epilogue
results.creator_credit: William Pettigrew, Bill Brind and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: From a glimpse of the beautiful planet we inhabit, as seen by astronauts in outer space, this film moves in for a closer look at what we are doing to it. The film employs the multi-image technique to contrast scenes of natural grandeur - mountains, forests, and wildflowers filmed in Canada’s national parks - with images such as the fouled rivers and despoiled countryside that result from the heedless exploitation of the natural environment. The challenge and the responsibility are plain for all to see. (Award: Teheran.)
results.creator_credit_for_label: William Pettigrew, Bill Brind and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Eora corroboree
results.creator_credit: Barbara A. Chobocky, Yuri Sokol, Michael Le Moignan and Corroboree Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Black futures (A)”.
For 40,000 years, the Aboriginal people of Australia had a rich and diverse culture, which sprang from and reflected their way of life and beliefs. Their culture was not written, but spoken, sung and performed. Since the coming of white man their culture has very nearly been destroyed. Aboriginal playwright, screenwriter and director Bob Merritt believes that a resurgence of Aboriginal culture is possible and in 1984 set up the Eora Centre for the Visual and Performing Arts in Redfern to offer young Aboriginals a comprehensive education in their traditional arts. Looks at the role of the Eora Centre and interviews some of its teachers and students.
